cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: ALL LETTERS TO BE ADDRESSED P.O.B. 810. 1.-Installation of complete Water supplies for drinking, agricultural, and
Industrial purposes by means of artesian wells. --Ono borlogs for prospecting purposes in all conditions of soll by means of the "Express Firing System."
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: COCOA SLAVERY
div.p: "One-fifth of all the cocok and chocolate we take is now produced for us by a form of black labour as truly slavery as anything on our own possessions before the Emancipation or on the plantations of the Southern States before the American Civil War." Thus Mı. H. W. Nevinson endeavours, in the course of a striking article in the September "Portnightly," to bring home to Englishmen their concern in the continuance of the Angola slave trade. A trade in slaves, beyond question, the contract labour system of the great | Portaguese province of sub-equatorial Africa

is proved to be. Mr. Nevinson recalls the first piteous evidence which he himself saw on the East and West road from the interior to Bengnella and Loanda - "innumerable shackles hanging on trees or strewn on the ground, skulls and bones lying on the path or in the bush close by, murdered men and women in every stage of decomposition, sometimes with the cleft of the axe visible in the skulls." Seized in dative fends, pawned to pay off ancestral or village debts, sold by Congo rebel soldiers, or raided over the frontier, such of the wretched victims as survive are disposed of either to the mainland | plantations - where they "work in gange, watched by drivers who urge them on with hippo whips or long pointed staves" - or to masters in the towns, where they do practically all the domestic and other work and are treated as absolute property, or to the cocoa islands of St. Thomas and Principe. About four thousand a year are exported to the islands, and, says Mr. Nevinson, "none ever come back."

This last is a peculiarly deadly fact. The Portuguese Government, which is as deeply pledged as we are ourselves to the abolition of slave-trading, says, and the Portuguese people no doubt believe, that a system of voluntary contract and repatriation is in effect. Mr. Nevinson declares that the contracts are fraudulent, and that they are regularly renewed without consent. "The climate," he adds, "in most parts, especially on Principe, is very unhealthy, the work is long and hard, the life entirely uninteresting and monotonous ; flogging with chicotte and palinatoria is common ; big dogs and sentries are kept to prevent the slaves running away ; if they are caught escaping in boats they are brought back and flogged ; if they escape to the forests as many do, the regulations provide for organized hunting parties. But as slavery goes, the treatment is not cruel, because cruelty is so expensive." For every slave it costs from £10 to £40. The later evidence which Mr. Nevinson offers in support of the case set forth in his recent book appears to be unanswerable. His most important proposal is that no five-yene contract should be renewable unless the native has first returned to the mainland. He suggests, as a last hope, a boycott by British and other cocoa manufacturers ; but we suggest that it will be time enough to try private influence when the representations to the Portuguese Government which the Foreign Office has expressed its willingness to make, have proved useless.

div.head: Arrival of Yacht.
div.p: The American yacht "Athena" arrived in harbour yesterday evening.

div.head: Egyptian University
div.p: The pupils of Daoud Salaama School have forwarded their ninth subscription towards the Egyptian University.

div.head: Polloe Budget
div.p: During the last 24 hours 6 thefts, 23 misdemeanours and 8 contraventions have taken place in Cairo.

div.head: Troop Parade.
div.p: The troops of the Egyptian Army will parade on the Observatory Ground at Abbassia, Cairo, on Thursday.

div.head: Exhumation of Body
div.p: The public prosecutor, has ordered the exhumation of the body of Proof Bey, son of Oof Pasba, victim of the automobile accident which occurred last week, for a post-mortem examination.

div.head: Suloide.
div.p: Aristides Joanides aged 30 years, employed in the Bank of Athens, married, and father of three children, threw himself into the Nile at Ghizeh. All search for his body has proved ineffectual. It is supposed that the deceased suffered from an incurable disease.

div.head: The Olive Moor"
div.p: The S.S. "Olive Moor", which grounded the night before last, is still in the same position. A salvage steamer has been telegraphed for and in the meantime every possible effort is being made to get her off the rocks. The weather this morning is more favourable and the cargo continues to be jettisoned with activity.

div.head: Ship on Fire
div.p: The British steamer "Jura" of Liverpool, Captain Fellows, arrived on the 30th ult. from the far East, landed at Suez a Lascar seamen who was rescued from the British S.S. "Fortunatas" of "Melbourne," this vessel being abandoned in Lat. 5" 5' S. Long. 90" 54 E on the 9th August. The "Fortunatus" was on fire when the seaman was taken from the vessel, which was shortly seen to be completely gutted by the flames. The rest of the crew of the "Fortunatus" got away in the ship's boats before the 8.3. "Jura had been sighted.

div.head: A Well-Deserved Lesson.
div.p: Yesterday morning a well-deserved lesson was given to an insolent European in the Rue de l'Ancienne Bourse for molesting a lady. For some time past the man had annoyed the lady by approaching her in the street and insulting her by his action. The lady complained to her husband, who arranged that she should walk down the street while he kept a short distance behind her. This the lady did and as usual the man accosted her, whereupon she struck him across the face, and the man had then to submit to probably the soundest thrashing from her husband to which he had ever been treated. A police officer intervened and arrested the man, who we trust will now have to suffer a severe punishment administered by the law.

div.head: A Disagreeable Contretemps.
div.p: A very disagreeable contretemps occurred recently to the housekeeper of a prominent official in the Fayoum. The lady in question, of the mildest disposition, was met by the cavass of the Greek Consulate on her arrival at Cairo, and requested to accompany him to the Hellenic Consulate under suspicion of being concerned with events of * a questionable character, in Upper Egypt which happened recently. The charge was completely unfounded and an error of the grossest nature had been committed by the cavass. The lady made the most vigorous protest and insisted on being conveyed to the Continental Hotel where her identity could be established. This was done and further annoyance obviated, but it is to be hoped that similar difficulties will be rendered, impossible in the future.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Pour répondre au désir des pères de famille, les projections cinématographiques du- jeudi et dimanche commenceront dorénavant à 7 heures, et le concert à 5 heures au lieu de 5.30 h.
Aujourd'hui à 5.30 grand concert donné par l'orchestre Bracale.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE PATHE
div.p: Programme du 2 au 9 septembre : L'Espagne en cartes postales, le cauchemar du charcutier, Rouget le braconnier, la course aux échasses, le Roman d'une chanteuse, vengeance de domestique, amour d'esclave, le cake-walk forcé et peintre moderne.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
COLLAPSE OF BUILDINGS.
div.p: On the 27th ulto. Mr. J.H. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can yet give any information as to the number of buildings which have collapsed in Alexandria, Cairo and their environs, in the past 12 months, and the number of persons thereby killed and injured.
Sir E. Grey. The report which has been called for on the subject has not yet been received.
STUDENTS FOR EUROPE.

Mr. John Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs if he can yet state the total amount of provision made by the Egyptian Government for sending students to Europe, and what prospect there is of increase in the number of qualified Egyptian teachers.

Sir E. Grey. The budget of the Egyptian Ministry of Education for 1908 has not yet been considered by the Council of Ministers and will not be finally settled till October. It is therefore impossible to say what the special credit alloted for the particular purpose will be.

I may state, however, that the Egyptian Ministry of Education is making arrangements with a view to sending this autumn 19 Egyptian students, a number not previously equalled, for training and further study in England, in addition to those who are already in this country undergoing special courses of instruction. It is hoped that all these Egyptian students, on the completion of their training, will enter the service of the Egyptian Government as teachers.
Mr. Rees asked whether it was right that the money of the Egyptian taxpayers should thus be expended in denationalising Egyptian students.

Sir E. Grey, replied that the object of the expenditure was to qualify Egyptian students to give the higher forms of instructions to their own countrymen, and that the expenditure of this kind was as proper in Egypt as elsewhere.
Mr. J. M. Robertson asked whether denationalising was not rather set up by the process of filling the Egyptian Civil Service with Englishmen. (Cheers.)
EDUCATION IN EGYPT.

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will obtain for the information of the House a classified list of professors who were employed by the Egyptian Government in teaching the sciences in Arabic at the date of the British occupation.

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will obtain for the information of the House a classified list of works, written in or translated into Arabic, upon scientific and technical subjects, and published in Arabic by the National Printing Press of Egypt, between the date of Mohamed Ali's accession, 1806, and that of the British occupation 1882.

Sir E. Grey. In answer to these questions, I must point out that I have already caused a great deal of extra, and in some cases laborious work on the part of officials in Egypt by asking for detailed information in reply to questions.

In this case I do not think it would be reasonable to ask them to make enquiries dating back to 1806. I do not know whether the information could be obtained, I do not suppose it could be obtained without much trouble, and when obtained, a list of persons and books could not be a guide to the value of the instruction given by them.

Mr. Robertson asked whether the required books could not be easily obtained from the catalogue of the Khedivial|Library; and whether such a list would not be a much better basis for conclusions as to the possibility of teaching the sciences in Arabic than the guesswork which had been hitherto presented to the House.
Sir E. Grey replied that without a knowledge of Arabic the House would not be able to draw any conclusion from such a list of books.
THE DENISHWAI SENTENCES

Mr. Lehmann Asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can state where the prisoners sentenced to penal servitude act Dinesh wai are carrying out their sentences, what is the nature of their labour, and if they are in irons: and whether if they had been tried under the ordinary law, such punishment as they are | now suffering could have been imposed on them.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey. My Rt. Hon friend has not the special information asked for on these points, but the sentences of the imprisonment are served in the same way as if they had been imposed by ordinary law.

Sir William Collins, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the decree of 1895, under which the Denishawi prisoners were tried, excludes all right of appeal against sentences ; and whether this also precludes the exercise of clemency, on the part of the Khedive in the case of capital sentences such as is provided for in the ordinary law of Egypt

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey - The text of the decree which the Hon. Members will find on p. 8 of Parliamentary Paper "Egypt No. 3 (1906)" states in the last paragraph of Article 4, that the sentences shall not be subject to appeal. If the Hon. Member will refer to p. 24 of the same Paper, he will see that the adoption of some procedure by which the decisions of the Special Tribunal shall be I confirmed by some superior authority is under consideration, and the Tribunal will not be called into existence without some euch provision.
THE SPECIAL TRIBUNAL.

Mr. Mackarness, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the deeree under which the special tribunal which tried the Denishwai prisoners was set up in any way prescribes what law is to be administered or what punishments may be inflicted and whether he can say if the law actually applied in the Denishwai trials was British, Egyptian or Mahommedan.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir B. Grey, My Rt. Hon. Friends can only refer to the Hon. Member to the text of the decree, which has been laid before Parliament, and to the observations of Lord Cromer as to the kind of punishments which should be in future prescribed if the Special Tribunal were again called into existence.
HAFEZ AWAD'S DEMANDS.

Mr. MacNeill,- To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he has received an outline of views and wishes of the Egyptian nation as regards changes in the administration of Egypt which have already been sanctioned by the general assembly at its recent meeting, forwarded to him as Member of the House of Commons by M. A. Hafiz Awad, the proposals for the establishment of the constitution being based on the schemes put forward by Lord Dufferin in 1883 ; whether he is aware that the programme of the Egyptian national party embraces free and compulsory education in all schools, the conferring of legislative powers on the general assembly and legislative council in matters relating purely to Egyptian affairs, the gradual substitution of Egyptian for European officials and the transference of the criminal jurisdiction of the consular courts to mixed courts with subsidiary grants ; and whether, having regard to the fact that these proposals are authoritatively declared to constitute the minimum of the reforms necessary for Egyptian needs and aspirations the Government will take any, and, if so, what steps in the immediate future towards their concession.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey replied :-My Rt. Hon. friend has received a communication of the nature described by the Hon. Member. But he has nothing to add to the statement of policy which he made in the debate on the Foreign Office Vote.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held yesterday morning at Alexandria when the following were approved :
1. The transfer of the French section from the Saaidieh to the Tewfikjeh School.
2. The opening of a credit of LE 19,500 to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration for the purchase of the dredger "St. Lawrence '' from the British Government.
3. The opening of a credit of L.E. 45,000 in excess of the credit allotted in the budget of the current year for the irrigation conversion works in Middle Egypt.
4. The opening of a supplementary credit of L.E. 6,737 for the strengthening of archæological monuments in Nubia.
3. The opening of a supplementary credit of LE. 5,000 for the completion of the Ghizeh reformatory.
6. The opening of a credit of L.E. 10,000 to the Public Health Department for fighting the bubonic and cattle plagues.
7. A credit of L. 2,976 for watering and scavenging new streets, at Rodah, Kasrel Aly, and Abbassieh
8. A credit of LE. 5,000 to the Public Works Department for helping the inhabitants of the Western Oasis to maintain their wells, to reopen old wells and dig new ones.
9. A credit of LE. 4,800 for the construction of barracks at Abbassieh.
10. The exemption of the Asile de Vieillards at Alexandria from the registration fee on a parcel of land purchased at Moharram Bey for the erection of a new Home.
11. An ordinance regulating the introduction and carriage of arms into Sudan.
12. The construction of five bridges over canals in Assonan province.
13. Declaration of public utility, the erection of houses for the railway staff at The elBaroud and other minor public works.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS
UPPER EGYPT MAIN LINE.
div.p: The double line from Maghaga to Minieh was opened on Sunday. This event marks another advance in the history of the State Railways including the entire modification of Etsa, Samallout, Klossana Mattai, Moaddah and Aba-el-Wakf stations also a new station at El Burquier between Esta and Minieh, a new deviation from kil. 178 to kil. 181 on which is the new Maghaga station goods yard and a new connection with the Sucreries Railways. The above work has been actively pushed ahead since the beginning of this year.

div.head: Cheap Cas from Common Fuels
div.p: for Engines, Manufacturing, Furnaces, Pumping, Irrigation, Incandescent Lighting and Generation of Electricity. Lane's Producers are available for Land, River or Ocean Service. Agents required. Address Howard Lane, 125 Edmund Street, Birmingham, England.

div.head:
THE YEMEN SITUATION.
UOUSA
WORSE THAN EVER
div.p: That the military situation in Yemen is worse than ever is evidenced by the outbreaks among the Turkish troops in the Yemen, which have become so frequent of late us to be unparalleled in the history of the Yemen campaign, and for which the treatment received | by the troops, and their arrears of pay is solely responsible. Advice received from Yemen states that a mutiny has broken out among the troops in Amran, which lies about three days from Sana. These troops are under the command of Ydssif Pasha, and about 3000 of them under arins have left Amran and proceeded to Hodeida, and from there they want to embark for their homes. They have now reached Manakha, and on their way from Amran they have given trouble to the people. * A telegraphic message was dispatched from Sanaa to Hodeidah informing the authorities to be on the lookout. Much apprehension is entertained at Hodeidah of coming trouble.

div.head: WEATHER DURING AUGUST.
div.p: We have received from the Survey Department the following report on the weather in Egypt and the Sudan during August 1907

The normal meteorological conditions in August are that a region of high pressure lies over the western Mediterranean and Northwest Africa, and in southern Africa in the neighbourhood of lat. 20°8. From these regions there is a steady gradient towards the Indian region of low pressure to the east of the Persian gulf. These conditions remain very constant giving steady breezes and clear skies as far as Dongola. South of this, southerly winds occur with frequent thunderstorms and rain.
During the past month pressure was in moderate excess in Egypt, and in large excess in Sudan. Temperature was above normal | in Egypt reaching 39° C at Helwan and 48 C
in Aswan, but in Sudan it was much below the average, the mean of the month near Khartoum, Dueim and Wad Medani being more than 2 below the pormal.

The distribution of the rainfall is remarkable ; at Khartoum, Kassala and Wad Medapi the amount recorded was in excess of the average by 144, 127 and 57 mm. respectively, while numerous washouts on the railways were reported.

In Eritrea rainfall at Adi Ugri was also in slight excess. In Abyssinia at Addis Ababa however there was a deficiency of 14 % in the first half of the month, and except for very heavy rainfall about the 20th which caused a large flood wave in both the Blue Nile and the Atbara there has not been a sustained improvement.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING
div.p: The Summary Court of Justice, Alexandria, has ordered the Boarse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited to pay indemnities to those employés who were dismissed without notice sums varying between three and four months' worth of their salaries.

div.head: TO KHARTOUM BY MOTOR
div.p: fbe ``Daily Mail '' reports that Mr. Bentley and Mr. Wells, two young Englishmen, who left Djibouti at the beginning of the month on an 18-h.p. car in an attempt to reach Khartoum, successfully crossed from Djibouti to Zeila. They left the latter place on Friday week for Dire Daoud, the present railhead, travelling via | Adagalla. Then they proceed to Addis Ababa, the capital of Abyssinia.
The journey has been one of immense difficulty, owing both to the sand of the desert and the mountainous district traversed, but the car has run splendidly.

div.head: LEMNOS AND EGYPT.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Liner "Osmanieh" will specially call on her way back from Constantinople at the island of Lemnos on the 7th September, where a considerable number of passengers will embark for Alexandria.
The majority of the Lemnos inhabitants are established in Egypt, and yearly many hundred pass their summer in that island which of late has become quite fashionable.
The island possesses hot mineral water baths, situated about 4 miles out of the town, and same are said to contain soda and magnesia and are proved to be excellent for indigestion, rheumatism
Lemnos is as well famous for partridge and | pigeon shooting, practically all the year round,

with the exception of the months of May, June, and July when shooting is prohibited. Owing to the fact that there is only one direct line of steamers from Lemnos to Alexandria of rather small tonnage, almost every season the visitors arrange for a liner to call and bring them back to Egypt.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The s.s. "Egyptian Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the end inet., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Friday.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major and Brevet Colonel G. F. Milne, D.8.O., commanding the 59th Battery Royal Field Artillery, Brighton, has been selected for a horse artillery Jacket," and has been placed under orders to proceed to Cairo to take up the command of the "U" Battery, R.H.A. Lieutenant Colonel Milne is a distinguished officer of the Royal Regiment. He obtained his first commission in 1885, was promoted captain in 1895, major in 1900, brevet Lieutenant colonel in 1902, and brevet colonel last year. His first active service experience was in the Nile Expedition, 1898, when he shared in the battle of Khartoum, Egyptian medal with clasp, (British medal) and he was on the staff during the South African War, 1899-1902, including the operations in the Orange Free State, the actions of Paardeberg, Poplar Grove, Vet River, and Zand River ; operations in the Transvaal, the actions of Johannesburg, Pretoria and Diamond Hill; and the operations generally in Cape Colony, Orange River Colony and the Transvaal down to the close of the war (mentioned in despatches, D.8.0., brevet lieutenant colonel, Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).
Captain W. H. Higginson, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been placed on duty with the draft for the 21st Battalion, at Alexandria, Egypt
The 1st Battalion Fusiliers, Malta, lately in Egypt, will leave that garrison on the 27th November next for Karachi, per the 8.8.
Dongola, and on arrival there will proceed to | Meerut and subsequently to Chakrata.

The Temeraire, which has just taken the water at Devonport, is the third of the Dreadnoughts. She is supposed to be an improvement on the original and the improved men's affected in her construction are being jealously guarded from the public. Very | little is known of her beyond that she measures 490 feet in length, has a beam of | 82 feet, and will have a displacement of | 18,400 tons when completed. She will be turbine engined, with an energy of 28,999 h.p., will be protected on the waterline by Ja 12 inch hardened steel belt along her entire length and will carry an armament of ten 12 inch 56 ton guns, and a number of smaller gans, of which the 7.5 will form a proportion. Her estimated speed is 21 knots. A lot of the details published about her are mere conjectures.
It is understood that the issue of the new naval uniform will be commenced on the 1st January next. The new caps, however, will not be issued until the stock now in hand is further reduced.

div.head: LOST LINK WITH NAPOLEON.
div.p: Probably few people, on reading the announcement of the death at Cape Town of Commissary General of Ordnance (retired) George Brooks Bonnett, formerly Chief Staff Paymaster of the Cape command, were aware of the fact that with him died the last remaining person who had seen the great Na poleon in the flesh. He was, says the "City | Press' ', the second son of the late Captain James Bennett, of the East India Company's service, and that officer was on duty at St. Helena at the time of the arrival there of Napoleon. Young George Bennett spent his childhood on the island, and had many opportunities of seeing the famous captive there, and was able in after-life to relate interesting anecdotes as to his early impressions and experiences. He came to England for his education, and when later, as a young officer, he was proceeding to the Cape, the ship he was in arrived at St. Helena at the time of the translation of the late Emperor's remains from the place of burial on the island to the French warship sent by King Louis Philippe to convey them to France. Commissary Bennet never returned to England, for, having served on the Cape command until he retired under the age conditions, he bought a charming house at Hof Street, near Cape Town, and spent his remaining days there. He had, therefore, no opportunities of being connected with the City, but his father, Captain Bennett, was admitted a Freeman in March, 1808, and his grandfather, Thomas Bennett, was a "Citizen and Joiner." Commissary Bennett was ninety-one years of age.

div.head: THE NEW TESTAMENT.*
div.p: This work consists of five lectures first published in "The Expository Times' ' (Oet. 1906 April 1907) and translated from the German by L.R.M. Strachan, M.A. Dr. Deissmann deals with the question of the discoveries of archaeologists in relation to Primitive Christianity. Whilst admitting the importance of the literary materials, he points out that these are only fragmentary, and protests against over estimating the worth of the purely literary evidence. The importance of the non-literary evidence, i.e. the innumerable texts on stone, metal, papyrus, | wood or clay has only been made accessible during recent years, and the author states that the recognition of their importance for the historical understanding of Primitive Chris tienity is still by no means general.
*Now Light on the New Testament, by Dr. A. Deinemann. T. and T. Qark, Edinburgh /

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, is expected at Cairo on Sunday morning.se
General Bellook is leaving next week for Cyprus to inspect the troops of that island. He will be accompanied by Lieutenant Fraser.

Wo regret to learn of the death of Bimbashi Bengough, Egyptian Army, An Army Order has been issued announcing that British officers of the Egyptian Army will wear mourning for the deceased until the 19th inst, inclusive.
| Mr. Bdward Mons arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Messageries Maritimes mail boat.
Mr. and Mps. Legrand have returned from their holiday in France. T
Mr. and Mrs. Athanassion retumed to Alexandria from Greece this morning.
Mohamed Bey Atif, secretary to the Minister of Public Instruction, and Mohamed Hamdi have been appointed inspectors of the new Kadis school.
Tuota

div.head: HORSESHOE DINNER.
div.p: As reported in our issue of yesterday the English jockeys of the Alexandria Sporting Club and several of their friends met at dinner on Saturday night at the Abbey Hotel under the presidency of Mr. N. Smith and with Mr. Taylor as vice-chairman This meeting, the first of what is to become an annual event, was a true sportsman's meeting, and it would have been gratifying to the owners of the stables to witness the friendship and bonne camaraderie existing between the sporting rivals who ride their horses for victory, and many of whom have attained it with brilliant.

As an introduction to the dinner the toast of the King and Constitution was drunk, and after that evidence of loyalty which is one of the most prominent characteristics of every true sportsman, the meeting settled down to dispose of as excellent a menn as has ever graced a table. With the advent of dessert the toast of the Guests was proposed by Mr. Nanny who coupled with it the names of Mr. Jenkins and Mr. Whiteside, from whose dinners in previous years the idea of instituting an annual horseshoe dinner originated. Mr. Whiteside responded and after the toast had been drunk with hearty acclamation, Mr. Stillwel! followed by a song. Mr. Taylor then proposed Sport, which was replied to by Mr. Jenkins, and the programme was next varied by a violin solo most sympathetically rendered by Mr. Smith. The Army and Navy, proposed by Mr.Clements, was the next tonat, and this was replied to by Mr. Murphy, and Mr. Macgregor then proposed a cordial toast to the Press which was responded to by Mr. Swanson, The toast of Commerce was given by Mr. Husky and responded to by Mr. Denman, and a special toast to Mr. Bonser as the oldest jockey of Alexandria, proposed by Mr. Taylor, was then received with "For he's a jolly good fellow." Mr. Wiloooks gave us the toast of Harmony, which indeed was the tone of the evening's meeting. Among those who contributed to the evening's enjoyment with songs were Mr. Jenkins, Mr. Bonser, Mr. Sidey, Mr. Galley, Mr. Wallacker, and Mr. Rance who recited "the Kissing Cup" from the well-known play "Run-a-look."
